properties.Description:
Percy Street required deep excavation for a new sewer, which led to the total replacement of the street and sub-base. This provided an excellent opportunity to apply porous asphalt.

Permeable materials, such as porous asphalt, are specially designed systems that allow water to soak through a typically impenetrable surface, significantly reducing stormwater runoff from a site.

Porous asphalt is as strong as conventional asphalt, but has voids in it that allow water to trickle through the material.

Benefits of porous asphalt include extended life of the street, decreased need for salting and snow removal, and significant reduction in stormwater runoff.

Maintenance to date has been a biannual vacuuming, although PWD is looking into using a street sweeping machine as well. Monitoring includes two internal observation wells, six nearby groundwater monitoring wells, and regular surface infiltration testing.

Additional advantages of permeable paving include: higher visibility of pavement markings, reduced noise due to surface absorbtion, reduces the "heat island" effect and reduced snow removal requirements and less potential for ice.
properties.Headline: The 800 block of South Percy Street is Philadelphia’s first porous street.
properties.Partners: Philadelphia Streets Department, Bella Vista Town Watch, Mayor's Office of Transportation and Utilities and the residents of 800 South Percy Street
properties.PublicFriendlyConversions: 4,915 gallons which is equal to 70 bathtubs
properties.cost:
Paving: $21000 
Stone base: $5,500 
Total job (water, sewer, curbs, footway and street paving): $330,000

properties.Description:
A series of streetside stormwater planters capture runoff from the contributing street and sidewalk areas. A stormwater planter manages street and sidewalk runoff through infiltration and evapotranspiration (or detention and slow-release when underlying soils do not allow for infiltration).

The stormwater planters benefit our streams and rivers by reducing stormwater flows into the overburdened combined sewer system, while benefiting the surrounding community through greening a significant sidewalk area and enhancing neighborhood aesthetics.

In 2012, Philadelphia Water returned to the site to install a rain garden at the corner of 12th and Reed.
properties.Headline: Columbus Square, in a densely populated South Philadelphia neighborhood, is an important demonstration site. Philadelphia Water built the first stormwater planters in the city at this site and later constructed an urban rain garden.
properties.Partners: Philadelphia Parks and Recreation, Streets Department, Columbus Square Park Advisory Council, Passyunk Square Civic Association, Green Club of the Christopher Columbus Charter School.
properties.PublicFriendlyConversions: stormwater planters capture 7,100 gallons, which is equal to 142 bathtubs

properties.Description: An infiltration system was built as part of a reconstruction of the playground to manage both on-site and off-site runoff from the adjacent streets. The basketball court was reconstructed and resurfaced with porous asphalt. A subsurface infiltration system was installed beneath the basketball court to manage stormwater runoff from portions of Earp St. and American St. A porous safety surface made from recycled tires, a rain garden and new trees were installed on this formerly tree-less site. Additional landscaping complements the stormwater features, mitigating the urban heat island effect, providing visual interest and creating a space for recreation.
properties.Headline: Herron Playground was a 100% impervious site and consisted of a pool, basketball court, play equipment and a large paved area before the park was redeveloped to include a porous basketball court, rain gardens, and stormwater trees.
properties.Partners: Philadelphia Parks and Recreation, Philadelphia Capital Program Office, and the Department of Public Property
properties.PublicFriendlyConversions: 44,337 gallons, which is equal to 633 bathtubs
properties.green tools: Subsurface detention system, porous paving, porous asphalt (basketball court), rain gardens and stormwater trees.
properties.storage volume: 5,972  cubic feet of storage (porous basketball court)

properties.Headline: Stormwater bumpouts at Dickinson Square collect runoff from Moyamensing Ave. In addition to infiltrating stormwater and nurturing plants, bumpouts provide traffic calming near a pedestrian crossing.
properties.Partners: Philadelphia Parks and Recreation, Friends of Dickinson Park and SEPTA
properties.PublicFriendlyConversions: 24,294 gallons, which is equal to 347 bathtubs

properties.Description:
Philadelphia Water awarded the project a $79,500 grant through SMIP, the Stormwater Management Incentives Program. In addition, the project qualifies for a $200 monthly credit on its stormwater bill.

As part of the redevelopment project, several stormwater management features were installed including the green roof, a rain garden in the parking lot and two subsurface infilration beds.

The green roof takes up about 67% of the roof area, and treats runoff from approximately 15,000 sf of roof. All together, the stormwater management features collect water from an area slightly larger than half a football field.

The redeveloped school building now holds 45 loft apartments and provides 38 parking spaces. The green roof is one of several amenities designed to attract residents to the building.
properties.Headline: Wharton Street Lofts, a former elementary school, was converted into apartments in 2014. Philadelphia Water provided a grant to the developer to incentivize stormwater management. Now, the building has a green roof that collects rainwater and boasts an excellent view of the city skyline.
properties.green tools: green roof, rain garden, subsurface infiltration basins

• Subsurface Infiltration Basin (12th St.): Drainage Area: 7,310 SF, Footprint: 1,439 SF, WQ Volume: 585.83 CF
• Rain Garden: Drainage Area: 5,377 SF, Footprint: 737 SF, WQ Volume: 384.33 CF
• Total Drainage Area managed: 34,579 SF

properties.green tools: Subsurface infiltration & detention basins, green roof, porous concrete pavers
